fields:
Denary Number System

Number system that is made up of {{c1::10 unique digits}}

Binary Number System

Number system that is made up of {{c1::2 unique digits}}

Hexadecimal Number System

Number system that is made up of {{c1::16 unique digits}}

Leading Zero

Zero digit (0) that is {{c1::to the left}} of {{c1::the first non-zero digit}} in a number

Internet Protocol (IP) Address

{{c1::Sequence of bytes}} that is used to {{c1::identify a computer or device on the Internet}}

Media Access Control (MAC) Address

{{c1::Sequence of bytes (usually permanent)}} that is used to {{c1::identify a particular network interface controller}}

IPv4 Address Format

{{c1::4 denary numbers}} separated by a {{c1::period}}
Example: 10.133.16.165

IPv6 Format

{{c1::8}} groups of {{c1::4 hexadecimal digits}} separated by a {{c1::colon}}

MAC Address Format

{{c1::6}} groups of {{c1::2 hexadecimal digits}} separated by a {{c1::colon}}
Example: 20:17:0B:AD:C0:DE

MAC Address Format

20:17:0B:AD:C0:DE

The {{c1::first three}} groups represent the {{c1::manufacturer's identity number}} and the {{c1::last three}} represent the {{c1::device’s serial number.}}

Manufacturer's Identity Number: 20:17:0B
Device’s Serial Number: AD:C0:DE

RGB Colour Code Format

RGB Colour Codes are made up of {{c1::three colour components}} represented by {{c1::two hexadecimal digits}} each. They are prefixed with a {{c1::number/pound/hashtag}} symbol.

Examples:
  • #FF0000 → Pure red
  • #00FF00 → Pure blue
  • #0000FF → Pure green
  • #800080 → Purple

Uses of the Denary Number System
  • {{c1::IPv4 Addresses}}
  • {{c1::ASCII Codes}}

Uses of the Binary Number System
  • {{c1::ASCII/Unicode Codes}}

Uses of the The Hexadecimal Number System
  • {{c1::IPv6 Addresses}}
  • {{c1::MAC Addresses}}
  • {{c1::HTML/RGB Colour Codes}}
  • {{c1::Memory Dumps}}

children.name: Unit 1.2 - Safe and Responsible Computer Use

fields:
Data Corruption

When data is {{c1::made unusable}} by {{c1::errors}} or {{c1::alterations}}

Data Loss

When data is {{c1::destroyed}} and {{c1::cannot be recovered}}

Backup

{{c1::Copy}} of {{c1::data}} that is made in case the original is {{c1::damaged or lost}}

Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS)

Device that {{c1::provides}} enough {{c1::emergency power}} for a {{c1::computer}} to {{c1::properly shut down}} in case of a {{c1::power failure}}

Authentication

Process of {{c1::verifying the identity}} of a {{c1::user}}

Authentication Factor

{{c1::Category}} of {{c1::evidence}} used for authentication, and is {{c1::something the user knows (e.g., a password)}}, {{c1::something the user owns (e.g., a phone)}}, or {{c1::something that is measured from a physical part of the user (e.g., fingerprint)}}

Unauthorised Access

Situation where data owned by someone is {{c1::used by someone else}}, such as {{c1::an intruder}}, {{c1::without permission}}

Security Token

Device that is used {{c1::specifically for authentication purposes}}

Two-factor Authentication

Type of authentication that uses evidence from both {{c1::something the user knows}} and {{c1::something the user owns}}

Biometrics

Type of authentication based on the {{c1::measurement of human physical characteristics}}

Identity Theft

{{c1::Impersonation}} of another person to {{c1::steal personal details such as name and identity number}} for  {{c1::fraudulent purposes}}

Authorisation/Access Control

Ability of a computer to {{c1::control a user’s access to data and resources}}

Firewall

{{c1::Device or computer program}} that {{c1::prevents unauthorised access}} to or from {{c1::a private network}}

Traffic

{{c1::Transmission of data over a network}}

Intranet

{{c1::Private}} network that only {{c1::authorised users within an organisation}} can access

Application

{{c1::Software designed for users to perform specific tasks}}

Encryption

Process of {{c1::encoding a message}} so that a {{c1::secret key}} is needed to {{c1::decode the data}}

Malicious Software/Malware

Software that is {{c1::intentionally}} used to {{c1::damage, disrupt or gain unauthorised access}} to {{c1::a computer system}}

Spamming

{{c1::Mass distribution}} of {{c1::unwanted messages or advertising}} to {{c1::email addresses}} which are collected from sources such as public mailing lists, social networking sites, company websites and personal blogs

Anti-spyware/Anti-virus

Software to {{c1::detect, remove and stop spyware/viruses and other malware}} from {{c1::running}}

Operating System

{{c1::Software designed to support a computer’s basic functions}}

Signature (malware)

{{c1::Unique evidence}} that is used to {{c1::detect a known version of some malicious software}}

Copyright

The {{c1::legal right of owners}} to {{c1::control the use and distribution}} of their {{c1::intellectual property}}

Intellectual Property

{{c1::Creations of the mind}} that {{c1::have value}} but {{c1::can exist purely as data with no physical form}}

Copyright Infringement

{{c1::Use or distribution of copyrighted work without the permission of the copyright owner}}

Plagiarism

{{c1::Passing off someone else’s original work as one’s own}}

Licence

{{c1::Official description}} of activities that are {{c1::authorised or forbidden}} by {{c1::the owner of intellectual property}}

Software piracy

{{c1::Crime}} of {{c1::copying, distributing and/or using proprietary software}} in a manner that is {{c1::not permitted by its licence}}

Free and Open-Source Software (FOSS)

Software where users are {{c1::given freedom to change, copy, study and share the software and its source code}}

Public Domain Software

Software where {{c1::the legal protections that are typically granted to intellectual property}} have either {{c1::expired, been surrendered or are simply inapplicable}}

Freeware

{{c1::Proprietary software that is available for use at no cost}}

Open Courseware

{{c1::Higher-education course materials}} such as {{c1::videos and notes}} created by {{c1::universities}} and {{c1::distributed for free on the Internet}}

Proprietary Software

{{c1::Commercial}} software for which {{c1::most of the legal protections under copyright are retained}}

Shareware

{{c1::Demonstration software}} that is {{c1::distributed for free but for a specific evaluation period only}}

Crack

{{c1::Program}} that modifies {{c1::proprietary software}} so that {{c1::the software cannot detect that it is being used illegally}}

Cookie

A {{c1::small file}} used by {{c1::websites}} to {{c1::store personal information on a user’s web browser}}

Pharming

The {{c1::interception of requests sent from a computer to a legitimate website}} and {{c1::redirection to a fake website}} to {{c1::steal personal data or credit card details}}

Phishing

The use of {{c1::emails and fake websites that appear to be from reputable companies}} in order {{c1::to steal personal information such as passwords and credit card numbers}} from {{c1::users}}

Spyware

A {{c1::hidden program}} that {{c1::secretly collects personal information about its users}} and {{c1::transmits this information to attackers without the users’ knowledge}}

Trojan horse

{{c1::A computer program that pretends to be a harmless file or useful application}}

Virus

A {{c1::computer program that attaches itself to a normally harmless program and modifies it}}. When the {{c1::modified program}} is run by a user, the virus {{c1::attaches copies of itself to any other programs it can find}}, thus {{c1::“infecting”}} them

Worm

A {{c1::computer program}} that {{c1::runs automatically}} and {{c1::attempts to spread by sending copies of itself to other computers}}. Unlike a virus, a worm {{c1::does not need to attach itself to an existing program}}

Causes of Unauthorised Access
  • {{c1::Poor authentication}}
  • {{c1::Poor access control or authorisation}}
  • {{c1::Poor understanding of privacy policies}}

Consequences of Unauthorised Access
  • Stolen {{c1::passwords or bank account information used to steal money and commit fraud}}
  • Intruders {{c1::publicising private information}} leading to {{c1::unwanted attention or bullying}}

Causes of Data Corruption and Loss
  • {{c1::Human Error}}
  • {{c1::Power Failure}}
  • {{c1::Hardware Failure or Damage}}
  • {{c1::Malicious Software or Viruses}}

Types of Privacy and Security Threats
  • {{c1::Cookie}}
  • {{c1::Pharming}}
  • {{c1::Phishing}}
  • {{c1::Spamming}}
  • {{c1::Spyware}}
  • {{c1::Trojan Horse}}
  • {{c1::Unauthorised Access}}
  • {{c1::Virus}}
  • {{c1::Worm}}

Measures Against Privacy and Security Threats
  • {{c1::Manage Cookies}}
  • {{c1::Identify Pharming}}
  • {{c1::Identify Phishing}}
  • {{c1::Manage Spam}}
  • {{c1::Anti-virus/Anti-spyware}}
  • {{c1::Update Software Regularly}}

Computer

Device that can {{c1::receive data, process the data}} according to {{c1::a set of instructions}} and {{c1::produce the processed data as a result}}

Computer Architecture

How a computer is {{c1::designed and built to function}}, including how {{c1::the parts of the computer are designed, organised and connected}}

Processor/Computer Processor

Processes {{c1::data}} and {{c1::follows instructions}}; consists of {{c1::an arithmetic logic unit}} and {{c1::a control unit}}

Data (singular: datum)

{{c1::Information}} that is {{c1::used in a computer program}}

Bit

{{c1::Binary digit}} which can take on the value {{c1::of either 0 or 1}}

Byte

{{c1::Binary number}} made up of {{c1::eight bits}}

Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU)

Part of {{c1::the processor}} that {{c1::processes data}} by {{c1::performing basic mathematical and logical operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication and division}}.

Control Unit

Part of {{c1::the processor}} that {{c1::follows instructions and decides when data should be stored, received or transmitted by different parts of the computer}} making sure that {{c1::data is transported to where it needs to be}}, and that {{c1::it is processed in the correct order}}.

Execute

{{c1::To follow or perform an instruction}}

Software

{{c1::Set of instructions to perform specific tasks on a computer}}

Address

{{c1::Number that is used to locate a byte in memory}}

Memory

{{c1::Device that is used to store data for immediate use in a computer}}

Hard disk (or hard drive)

{{c1::Secondary storage where data is stored on rigid rotating disks coated with a magnetic material}}

Volatile

{{c1::Lost when the power supply is interrupted}}

Processor registers

{{c1::Extremely fast but small data storage spaces}} used directly by {{c1::the ALU and control unit}}. The {{c1::number and size}} of processor registers cannot be changed {{c1::without changing the processor}}.

Random Access Memory (RAM)/Main Memory

Where {{c1::data and instructions are stored temporarily}} so that they {{c1::can be quickly accessed by the processor when needed}}. Data stored on RAM is {{c1::easily changed and is volatile}}.

Read-only memory (ROM)

Where {{c1::data and instructions that rarely need to change or would be needed for a computer to start up are stored}}. Data stored on ROM {{c1::cannot be easily changed and is non-volatile}}.

Bus

{{c1::Collection of wires}} for {{c1::transporting data from one part of a computer to another}}

Bi-directional

{{c1::Able to work in two directions}}

Uni-directional

{{c1::Able to work in one direction only}}

Data bus

{{c1::Bi-directional}} bus that {{c1::is used to transport data between memory and the processor}}

Address bus

{{c1::Uni-directional}} bus that is {{c1::used to transport required memory location from processor to memory}}

Input (computer architecture)

{{c1::Data or instructions that the computer receives for processing}}

Output (computer architecture)

{{c1::Intermediate or final results produced by the computer in the form of processed data}}

Hardware

{{c1::Physical part of a computer}}

Input device

Hardware device {{c1::that allows users to enter data and instructions into a computer}}
Example: Mouse, keyboard, webcam, touch screen, microphone, scanner

Output device

Hardware device {{c1::used to display, project or print processed data from a computer}}
Example: Printer, speakers, display/monitor

Secondary Storage

{{c1::Way of storing large amounts of data that will not be lost when power supply is interrupted}}

Magnetic Storage Media

{{c1::Data is stored on a magnetic material that can be read or written by a magnetic “head”}}

Optical Storage Media

{{c1::Data is stored as very small pits or indentations that can be read or written by a laser}}

Solid-state Storage Media

{{c1::Data is stored in electronic circuits called “flash memory” that have no moving parts}}

Truth Table

{{c1::Table that shows the resulting output for every possible combination of inputs}}

Logic Gate

{{c1::An electrical circuit that performs logical operations based on one or more inputs and produces a single output}}

Logical Operation

{{c1::An operation that acts on binary inputs to produce an output according to the laws of Boolean logic}}

Logic Circuit

{{c1::A circuit that consists of only one logic gate or multiple logic gates connected together}}

Logic Circuit Diagram

Visual representation using {{c1::symbols}} to {{c1::show how the component logic gates are connected together in a logic circuit}}

Types of Storage Media
  • {{c1::Magnetic}} (ex: {{c1::Hard Drive/Hard Disk Drive (HDD)}})
  • {{c1::Optical}} (ex: {{c1::Digital Versatile Disc (DVD)}})
  • {{c1::Solid-state}} (ex: {{c1::Secure Digital Card (SD Card)}})

Factors in Comparing Storage Mediums
  • {{c1::Capacity}}
  • {{c1::Speed}}
  • {{c1::Portability}}
  • {{c1::Durability}}
  • {{c1::Cost}}

Logic Gates
  • {{c1::OR}}
  • {{c1::AND}}
  • {{c1::NOT}}
  • {{c1::NOR (equiv to NOR OR)}}
  • {{c1::NAND (equiv. to NOT AND)}}

Computer Network

System of {{c1::two or more computers that are connected together by a transmission medium}} for {{c1::the exchange of data}}.

Transmission Medium

Means of {{c1::connecting two or more computers together}}, such as using {{c1::copper cables, radio waves or light pulses}}, so that {{c1::they may exchange data and interact with each other}}

Local Area Network (LAN)

Network of {{c1::computing devices connected within a small geographical area}}, typically {{c1::within the same building, such as a home, school or office}}

Metropolitan Area Network (MAN)

Network of {{c1::computing devices}} typically {{c1::spanning across two or more buildings within the same town or city}}

Wide Area Network (WAN)

Network of {{c1::computing devices}} typically {{c1::covering a large-scale geographical area, typically across multiple geographical locations}}

Ethernet

Most commonly used {{c1::wired network protocol}} for {{c1::local and metropolitan area networks}}

Network Protocol

{{c1::Set of standards and rules}} that {{c1::govern how two or more devices communicate over a network}}

Wired Network

Network of {{c1::devices}} connected by a {{c1::physical medium}}, such as {{c1::cables}}

Wireless Network

Network of {{c1::devices}} in which {{c1::signals are transmitted without the use of a physical medium}}

Client

{{c1::Computer}} that {{c1::initiates a connection to a server}} to {{c1::request for resources and services to perform operations}}

Server

{{c1::Computer}} that {{c1::shares resources with and responds to requests from devices and other servers on the network}}

Wireless Access Point (WAP)

Network hardware that {{c1::provides a connection between wireless devices up to 100 metres away}} and {{c1::can connect to wired networks}}

Bandwidth

The {{c1::average number of bits of data that can be transmitted from a source to a destination over the network in one second}}; is usually measured in {{c1::megabits per second (Mbps)}} or {{c1::gigabits per second (Gbps)}}

Port Number

Number that is used together with an {{c1::IP address}} to {{c1::uniquely identify a program that is running on a network}}

Service Set Identifier (SSID)

A {{c1::32-byte string}} that identifies {{c1::a wireless access point (WAP) and all devices connected to it}}

Packet (computing)

A {{c1::unit}} of {{c1::broken-up data containing a header with information about the source and destination addresses that are needed for transmission}}

Network Interface Controller/Card (NIC)

A network interface controller/card (NIC) provides the {{c1::hardware interface}} to {{c1::enable the transfer of data between a device and a network}}.

A NIC may {{c1::connect}} to a network {{c1::physically or wirelessly}}.

{{c1::Most devices}} are {{c1::equipped}} with a built-in NIC.

Hub/Network Hub

Device that {{c1::transmits received packets to all connected devices}}. Likewise, when {{c1::a device responds}}, the {{c1::response is sent to every device that is connected to the hub}}.

Switch/Network Switch

Device that {{c1::constructs a single network by connecting multiple similar networks together}}.

A switch uses {{c1::MAC addresses}} to {{c1::keep track of the devices that are connected to it}}.

This lets the switch intelligently decide whether {{c1::it should drop or forward the packets that it receives}}.
Note: A switch that connects exactly two networks together is also called a network bridge.

Router

Device that {{c1::forwards packets between separate networks}}, keeping {{c1::the connected networks (which may use fundamentally different protocols) separate}} and {{c1::forwards packets between them using Internet protocols}}.

Demodulation

{{c1::Conversion of transmitted signals into digital data}}

Modem (short for “modulator-demodulator”)

{{c1::Device responsible for modulation and demodulation}}

Modulation

{{c1::Conversion of digital data into a form suitable for transmission}}

Parity Bit

{{c1::Additional}} bit, which can {{c1::either be 0 or 1 depending on whether an odd or even parity system is used}}, {{c1::appended or prepended to a string of binary data before transmission}}

Parity Check

{{c1::Error-checking technique which uses a parity bit to detect errors}}

Checksum

{{c1::Calculated value used to determine the integrity of transmitted data}}

Advantages of a Computer Network
  • {{c1::Shared Resources}}
  • {{c1::Shared Internet Access}}
  • {{c1::Shared Software}}
  • {{c1::Shared Storage}}
  • {{c1::Communication}}

Disadvantages of a Computer Network
  • {{c1::Inital Costs}}
  • {{c1::Maintenance Costs}}
  • {{c1::Security Risks}}
  • {{c1::Risk of Data Loss}}
  • {{c1::Server Outage}}

Comparing Area Networks
In order of increasing size:
  1. {{c1::Land Area Network (LAN)}}
  2. {{c1::Metropolitan Area Network (MAN)}}
  3. {{c1::Wide Area Network (WAN)}}

Examples of Server-Provided Resources and Services
  • {{c1::Providing central storage of files}}
  • {{c1::Sharing hardware such as printers}}
  • {{c1::Controlling logins and network access}}

Network Topologies
  • {{c1::Bus}}
  • {{c1::Ring}}
  • {{c1::Star}}

Components of a Simple Home Network
In order of connection:
  1. {{c1::Modem}}
  2. {{c1::Router}}
  3. {{c1::Switch}}
  4. {{c1::Hub}}
  5. {{c1::Network Interface Card (NIC)}}

Error-Checking Methods
  • {{c2::Parity Check}}
  • {{c1::Checksum}}

Checksum Series of Events
  1. {{c1::Before transmission, a checksum is calculated.}}
  2. {{c1::The data and the checksum is sent together.}}
  3. {{c1::At the destination, the checksum is calculated and compared to the sent checksum value.}}
  4. {{c1::If the checksums match, the data was transmitted correctly. Else, an error has occured.}}

Method to Calculate a One-byte Checksum
  • {{c1::If the sum of all bytes in the data is less than or equal to 255, the checksum is this value.}}
  • {{c1::If the sum is greater than 255, the checksum is the modulus of 256. (e.g., sum = 1350 % 256 = 70)}}

Algorithm

{{c1::Set of step-by-step instructions for solving a problem}}

Input (algorithms)

{{c1::Data}} used by an algorithm that {{c1::can affect what is required for correct output}}

Output (algorithms)

{{c1::Results}} produced by an algorithm

Solution

{{c1::Algorithm}} that always gives {{c1::correct outputs}} when {{c1::provided with valid inputs}}

Sub-problem

A problem whose {{c1::solution contributes to the solution}} of a {{c1::bigger problem}}

Decomposition

{{c1::Breaking down}} a {{c1::complex problem}} into {{c1::smaller and more manageable parts}}

Pattern Recognition

{{c1::Identifying similarities}} among {{c1::two or more items}}

Generalisation

{{c1::Technique}} of {{c1::replacing two or more similar problems or solutions}} with a {{c1::single, more general problem or solution}}

Dry run

{{c1::Process of running through a set of steps manually}}

Test data

{{c1::Input}} data that is used to {{c1::perform a dry run}}

Trace table

{{c1::Tabulation}} of the {{c1::change in variables}} as well as the {{c1::output}} of an {{c1::algorithm}}

Pseudo-code

{{c1::Description}} of an {{c1::algorithm}} using {{c1::natural language}} mixed with {{c1::sequence, selection and iteration constructs}}

Problem Decomposition Approaches
  • {{c1::Incremental Approach}}
  • {{c1::Modular Approach}}

Pattern Recognition
  • {{c1::Identifying patterns among two or more problems.}}
  • {{c1::Identifying patterns among two or more solutions.}}
  • {{c1::Identifying patterns among two or more steps in a solution.}}

Instruction Set

Set of {{c1::basic commands or instructions}} that a {{c1::processor can understand directly}}, represented in {{c1::byte form}}

Machine Code

{{c1::Instructions}} that can run {{c1::directly on a computer’s processor}}

Program

{{c1::Set of instructions written to perform specific tasks on a computer}}

Programming Language

Language designed for {{c1::humans to communicate instructions to computers}}

Source Code

{{c1::Instructions written in a programming language that both humans and computers can understand}}

Syntax

{{c1::Rules that determine how the words and symbols in a valid instruction are arranged}}

Compiler

{{c1::Code translator program}} that {{c1::translates source code into machine code completely}} before running the {{c1::compiled program}}

Interpreter

{{c1::Code translator program}} that {{c1::translates source code into machine code}} while {{c1::the interpreted program is running}}

Type Casting

{{c1::Process of converting a value from one data type to another}}

Concatenation

{{c1::Joining two sequences to make a longer sequence}}

Control Flow Statement

{{c1::Programming instruction that changes the order in which other instructions are run}}
Example: Python if-elif-else statement

Test Case

A {{c1::set of inputs}} and the corresponding {{c1::set of expected outputs}} for a particular program {{c1::used to verify whether the program works as intended}}

Testing

{{c1::Process by which defects in a program can be detected}}

Module

{{c1::Collection of variables and functions}} that need to be {{c1::loaded before they can be used}}

Character

A {{c1::unit of information}} for {{c1::strings}}, usually a symbol, letter or digit.

Check Digit

Digit or letter that is {{c1::added to a sequence of digits to detect errors in manual input}}

Data Validation

{{c1::Process}} of {{c1::ensuring that the input data supplied to a system satisfies a set of rules}} such that it is {{c1::sensible, complete and within acceptable boundaries}}.

Length Check

{{c1::Process of ensuring that input data is not too short or too long}}

Range Check

{{c1::Process of ensuring that input data is within the required range of values}}

Presence Check

{{c1::Process of ensuring that all the required inputs are provided}}

Format Check

{{c1::Process of ensuring that input data matches a required arrangement or pattern}}

Crash

{{c1::Sudden stop of a program due to an error}}

Hang

{{c1::Unresponsiveness of a program due to an error}}

Run-time Error

Error that {{c1::occurs while the program is running}}

Logic Error

Error that causes {{c1::the output of a program to be different from what is expected}}

Syntax Error

Error as a {{c1::result of incorrect source code that does not follow the rules of the language}}

Normal Conditions (programming)

Situations where {{c1::input data follows what is expected during normal use of the program}}

Boundary Conditions (programming)

Situations where {{c1::input data is at the limit of what the program is designed to cope with or where special handling is required}}

Error Conditions (programming)

Situations where {{c1::input data would normally be rejected by the program}}

Bug

{{c1::Defect in a program that causes it to behave in an unintended manner}}

Debugging

{{c1::Process of identifying and removing defects from a program}}

Stages of Program Development
  • {{c1::Gather requirements}}
  • {{c1::Plan solutions}}
  • {{c1::Write code}}
  • {{c1::Test and refine code}}
  • {{c1::Deploy code}}

Data Validation Techniques
  • {{c1::Length check}}
  • {{c1::Range check}}
  • {{c1::Presence check}}

Types of Program Errors
  • {{c1::Syntax errors}}
  • {{c1::Run-time errors}}
  • {{c1::Logic errors}}

note_models.name: Cloze
